contents.text: The OSI Model stands for Open Systems Interconnection Model.
It is a conceptual framework that standardizes the functions of a telecommunication or computing system into seven abstraction layers.
Each layer serves a specific purpose and interacts with the adjacent layers to facilitate communication between devices.
The seven layers of the OSI Model are: Physical, Data Link, Network, Transport, Session, Presentation, and Application.
The Physical layer deals with the physical connection between devices and the transmission of raw data bits over a physical medium.
The Data Link layer provides error detection and correction, as well as framing and flow control.
The Network layer is responsible for routing packets between different networks.
The Transport layer ensures end-to-end communication, segmenting and reassembling data as needed.
The Session layer establishes, maintains, and terminates connections between applications.
The Presentation layer is responsible for data translation, encryption, and compression.
The Application layer provides interfaces for user applications to access network services.
TCP/IP Protocol Suite is a set of communication protocols used for connecting network devices on the internet.
The TCP/IP Protocol Suite consists of four layers: Application, Transport, Internet, and Link.
The Application layer is responsible for providing high-level data exchange between applications.
The Transport layer ensures reliable data delivery and manages end-to-end communication.
The Internet layer handles addressing and routing of data packets across different networks.
The Link layer deals with physical connections and data transfer within the local network.
TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) is a connection-oriented protocol that provides reliable data delivery.
IP (Internet Protocol) is a connectionless protocol responsible for addressing and routing packets.
An example of an application layer protocol is HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol) used for web browsing.
An example of a transport layer protocol is TCP, ensuring reliable data transmission.
An example of an internet layer protocol is IPv4 (Internet Protocol version 4) for addressing and routing packets.
An example of a link layer protocol is Ethernet for wired local area network connections.
IPv4 addresses are 32-bit numerical addresses expressed in decimal format, divided into four octets separated by periods.
IPv6 addresses are 128-bit hexadecimal addresses, separated by colons and can include letters from A to F.
IPv4 addresses are limited in number due to the 32-bit address space, resulting in approximately 4.3 billion unique addresses.
IPv6 addresses provide a significantly larger address space compared to IPv4, allowing for an almost unlimited number of unique addresses.
IPv4 addresses use subnet masks to divide the address into network and host portions.
IPv6 addresses use CIDR notation to specify the network prefix length.
Routing protocols determine how data packets are forwarded from one network to another.
There are two main types of routing protocols: distance vector and link-state.
Examples of distance vector routing protocols include RIP (Routing Information Protocol) and EIGRP (Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol).
Examples of link-state routing protocols include OSPF (Open Shortest Path First) and IS-IS (Intermediate System to Intermediate System).
Routing protocols use algorithms to determine the best path for data packets to reach their destination.

Router: A network device that forwards data packets between computer networks. Routers operate at Layer 3 (Network layer) of the OSI model.
Switch: A network device that connects devices within a network by using packet switching to forward data to the intended recipient. Switches operate at Layer 2 (Data Link layer) of the OSI model.
Firewall: A network security device that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules. Firewalls can be hardware or software-based.
Hub: A basic networking device that connects multiple devices in a network. Hubs operate at Layer 1 (Physical layer) of the OSI model and simply broadcast data to all connected devices.
LAN (Local Area Network) is a network that is confined to a small geographic area, such as a single building or a campus.
Example: A company's internal network connecting all computers and devices within the office building is an example of a LAN.
WAN (Wide Area Network) spans a large geographical area, connecting multiple LANs and other networks together across cities, countries, or even continents.
Example: The internet is the largest example of a WAN, connecting networks globally.
MAN (Metropolitan Area Network) covers a larger geographic area than a LAN but smaller than a WAN, typically serving a city or a region.
Example: A network connecting various university campuses within a city is an example of a MAN.
Wireless Networks are networks that use radio waves to transmit data between devices without the need for physical connections.
Types of wireless networks include Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, cellular networks (3G, 4G, 5G), and satellite networks.
Wireless networks can be secured using encryption protocols such as WPA2, WPA3, and VPNs to protect data transmission from unauthorized access.
Wireless networks can be set up using routers, access points, and wireless adapters to enable devices to connect to the network wirelessly.

Common issues in wireless networks include interference from other devices, signal range limitations, and security vulnerabilities that can be mitigated through proper network configuration and monitoring.
